We are also seeing a decrease in the amount of capital expenditures related to our other businesses. This is because we are reducing our investments in our other businesses and selling off certain assets to reduce debt and the associated debt-service. results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.markdown_table_response:
The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets is determined by using valuation techniques. These valuation techniques maximise the use of observable market data where it is available and rely as little as possible on entity specific estimates. If all significant inputs required for evaluating the fair value of a financial instrument are observable, the instrument is included in level 2.
If one or more of the significant inputs are not based on observable market data, the instrument is included in level 3.
Specific valuation techniques used to value financial instruments mainly include: • Dealer quotes for similar instruments; • The fair value of interest rate swaps is calculated as the present value of the estimated future cash flows based on observable yield curves; and • Other techniques, such as discounted cash flow analysis, are used to determine fair value for financial instruments.
results.csv_string_response: The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets is determined by using valuation techniques.

As another example, we do not consider certain acquisition-related expenses to be indicative of our core operating performance because such expenses do not represent capital expenditures by the company. Rather, we consider acquisition-related expenses to be indicative of our core operating performance when the acquisition is primarily for our benefit and the expenses are incurred for the purpose of expanding our business in the same manner as we would expand a business. In addition, we do not consider certain other expenses that we do not consider to be indicative of our core operating performance. Film and Electrolytic net sales of $203.0 million in fiscal year 2018 increased $19.7 million or 10.8% from $182.2 million in fiscal year 2017. The increase in net sales was primarily driven by an increase in net sales in the distributor channel across all the APAC and EMEA regions of $11.9 million, a $2.9 million increase in net sales in the OEM channel of the EMEA region and a $2.4 million increase in the EMS channel across the Americas, EMEA, and APAC regions. These increases were partially offset by a decrease in net sales of $1.2 million in the OEM channel across the Americas, APAC, and JPKO regions.
